Definition: Labyrinthitis is an inner ear disorder that involves inflammation of the labyrinth, affecting balance and hearing.
Causes: Viral infections, bacterial infections, and head injuries.
Symptoms: Dizziness, hearing loss, and tinnitus.
Diagnosis: Physical examination, hearing tests, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Medications for symptoms, antibiotics if bacterial, and vestibular rehabilitation.

Definition: Laryngeal cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the larynx (voice box).
Causes: Smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and HPV infection.
Symptoms: Hoarseness, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing.
Diagnosis: Laryngoscopy, imaging studies, and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Laryngopharyngeal reflux is a condition where stomach acid flows back into the throat, causing irritation.
Causes: Weak lower esophageal sphincter, obesity, and certain foods.
Symptoms: Hoarseness, chronic cough, and throat clearing.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and sometimes pH monitoring.
Treatment: Dietary changes, medications, and lifestyle modifications.

Definition: A lateral collateral ligament (LCL) tear is an injury to the ligament on the outer side of the knee.
Causes: Direct impact to the inner knee or excessive twisting.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and instability in the knee.
Diagnosis: Physical examination and imaging studies.
Treatment: Rest, ice, compression, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Leiomyosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that arises from smooth muscle tissue.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic mutations.
Symptoms: Lump or mass, pain, and swelling.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Leukemia is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow.
Causes: Genetic factors, exposure to radiation, and certain chemicals.
Symptoms: Fatigue, frequent infections, and easy bruising.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, bone marrow biopsy, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and stem cell transplant.

Definition: Liposarcoma is a rare cancer that arises from fat cells in soft tissue.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic mutations.
Symptoms: Lump or mass, pain, and swelling.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Liver cancer is a type of cancer that originates in the liver.
Causes: Chronic liver disease, hepatitis B and C, and cirrhosis.
Symptoms: Weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, blood tests, and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy.

Definition: Liver cirrhosis is a late-stage scarring of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions.
Causes: Chronic alcohol abuse, hepatitis, and fatty liver disease.
Symptoms: Fatigue, easy bruising, and swelling in the legs and abdomen.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, imaging studies, and liver biopsy.
Treatment: Managing symptoms, lifestyle changes, and liver transplant in severe cases.

Definition: Liver disease refers to any condition that damages the liver and affects its function.
Causes: Alcohol abuse, viral infections, and fatty liver disease.
Symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, imaging studies, and liver biopsy.
Treatment: Depends on the specific disease; may include medications and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Loeys-Dietz syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue and can lead to cardiovascular issues.
Causes: Genetic mutations, often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Symptoms: Aneurysms, skeletal abnormalities, and skin changes.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and genetic testing.
Treatment: Monitoring and management of cardiovascular issues, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Long QT syndrome is a heart rhythm disorder that can potentially lead to fast, chaotic heartbeats.
Causes: Genetic factors, certain medications, and electrolyte imbalances.
Symptoms: Palpitations, fainting, and in severe cases, sudden cardiac arrest.
Diagnosis: Electrocardiogram (ECG) and family history.
Treatment: Medications, lifestyle changes, and sometimes implantable devices.

Definition: Low blood pressure, or hypotension, is a condition where blood pressure is lower than normal.
Causes: Dehydration, heart problems, and endocrine disorders.
Symptoms: Dizziness, fainting, and fatigue.
Diagnosis: Blood pressure measurements and medical history.
Treatment: Increased fluid intake, medications, and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Lung cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the lungs.
Causes: Smoking, exposure to secondhand smoke, and environmental toxins.
Symptoms: Coughing, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, sputum cytology, and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapy.

Definition: Lung disease refers to any condition that affects lung function.
Causes: Infections, chronic diseases, and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.
Diagnosis: Pulmonary function tests, imaging studies, and blood tests.
Treatment: Depends on the specific disease; may include medications and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Lung neuroendocrine tumors are a group of tumors that arise from neuroendocrine cells in the lungs.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Cough, chest pain, and difficulty breathing.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy.

Definition: Lung sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects the lungs and can cause granulomas.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve immune system response.
Symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, lung function tests, and biopsy.
Treatment: Monitoring, corticosteroids, and immunosuppressive medications.

Definition: Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and fever.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, clinical evaluation, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Medications to manage symptoms and prevent flares.

Definition: Lupus nephritis is a complication of lupus that affects the kidneys.
Causes: Autoimmune response leading to inflammation in the kidneys.
Symptoms: Swelling, high blood pressure, and changes in urine.
Diagnosis: Urine tests, blood tests, and kidney biopsy.
Treatment: Immunosuppressive medications and management of kidney function.

Definition: Lyme disease is an infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacteria, transmitted through tick bites.
Causes: Bites from infected black-legged ticks.
Symptoms: Fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and laboratory tests.
Treatment: Antibiotics and supportive care.

Definition: Lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, fever, weight loss, and night sweats.
Diagnosis: Biopsy, imaging studies, and blood tests.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapy.

Definition: Lynch syndrome is a hereditary condition that increases the risk of certain cancers, particularly colorectal cancer.
Causes: Genetic mutations in mismatch repair genes.
Symptoms: Increased risk of colorectal and other cancers.
Diagnosis: Family history assessment and genetic testing.
Treatment: Increased surveillance, preventive surgery, and management of cancers.
